headline.text: Trump Decries Tactic of ‘Flipping’ Criminal Defendants

articles.summary: President Trump, speaking after Michael Cohen implicated him in a federal crime in a plea deal, said so-called flipping “almost ought to be illegal.” He also renewed his attacks on Attorney General Jeff Sessions, asking “What kind of man is this?”

bullets.title: Michael Cohen: Full Coverage

headline.text: Why Cohen Agreed to Plead Guilty—And Implicate the President

articles.summary: Prosecutors had reams of evidence and a long list of counts, which also could have included the lawyer’s wife. The moment Cohen stood up in court, he opened a new legal front for Trump that is fraught with peril.
articles.byline: Rebecca Davis O’Brien, Nicole Hong and Joe Palazzolo

bullets.title: How the Money Flowed

headline.text: DNC Says Reported Hack Attempt Was a False Alarm

articles.summary: A suspected attempt to hack into the Democratic National Committee’s voter database was actually a cybersecurity test, the organization said.

headline.text: The New Gas Market: Shipowners Needing Cleaner Fuel

articles.summary: The global shipping industry could become a new market for liquefied natural gas, thanks to a drastic change in maritime law that aims to curb air pollution.

headline.text: Women Rescued From ISIS Are Told to Leave Children Behind

articles.summary: Women from Iraq’s Yazidi minority, freed from Islamic State captivity, have been forced to choose between the children fathered by their captors and returning to their conservative community.

media.caption: A resident looks out from a shelter for Yazidi women rescued from Islamic State captivity, in Duhok, Iraq.
media.credit: Alexandra R. Howland for The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: As Central Bankers Meet, Economic Uncertainties Weigh on Sunny Outlook

articles.summary: The formal discussion at this week’s Fed retreat with global central bankers will be about the impact of monopolies, but new economic uncertainties are sure to dominate chats over cocktails and mountain hikes.

bullets.title: Fed Signals Rate Increase Next Month

headline.text: Strong Consumption Breathes New Life Into Retail Stocks

articles.summary: U.S. consumer spending is so strong that it’s even boosting shares of left-for-dead retailers. While bricks-and-mortar chains have struggled to transform themselves, many are being helped along by Americans’ increasing willingness to spend.

bullets.title: Target Rides Retail Surge

headline.text: Dearth of a Salesman: Dealerships Struggle to Attract Younger Workers

articles.summary: Car dealerships are facing a roadblock: convincing workers in their 20s and 30s to work and stay in an auto retail business defined by long shifts, weekends on the selling floor, haggling and commission-based pay.

headline.text: Saudi Arabia Denies Aramco IPO Is Canceled

articles.summary: Saudi Arabia said it remained committed to publicly listing Aramco, its national oil company, at some point in the future, dismissing reports that the centerpiece of the country’s economic transformation had been canceled.
articles.byline: Summer Said, Rory Jones and Ben Dummett

bullets.title: Analysis: Aramco Could Still Sell a Stake—to China

headline.text: China, U.S. Fire Off New Tariffs in Middle of Trade Talks

articles.summary: China and the U.S. launched a fresh round of tariffs on $16 billion in each other’s goods, even as officials from both governments sat down for negotiations to resolve their monthslong trade fight.

headline.text: A Year After Harvey, Some Texans Are Still Suffering

articles.summary: A year after Hurricane Harvey, Texas residents in hard-hit areas say they still face financial struggles and need more help repairing their homes and getting sufficient aid, according to a new survey.

headline.text: Alibaba Earnings Slump on One-Time Charge

articles.summary: Chinese e-commerce titan Alibaba said fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 41%, driven by a one-off stock compensation charge from the revaluation of its financial-services affiliate.

headline.text: Ohio State Suspends Urban Meyer for Three Games

articles.summary: Ohio State suspended football coach Urban Meyer and athletic director Gene Smith after an investigation concluded they failed to take sufficient action following domestic violence accusations against former assistant coach Zach Smith.

articles.summary: The state closed schools and some government offices and opened emergency shelters as it prepared for a hurricane with sustained winds of 155 miles an hour.

headline.text: Sorry, Pal, I Don’t Want to Talk: The Other Reason People Wear AirPods

articles.summary: Apple’s white wireless earphones transmit music and conversations, but some users wear them all day as a shield, a secretary and a hiding place.

headline.text: Cannabis Supply Chains Coming Out of the Shadows

articles.summary: A nascent network of distributors is sprouting in California, taking marijuana business “from backpack to briefcase” in a potential model for national supply chains.

headline.text: Coca-Cola Launched 500 Drinks Last Year. Most Don’t Taste Like Coke.

headline.text: Kroger to Ditch Plastic Bags by 2025

articles.summary: Kroger plans to eliminate plastic shopping bags from its supermarkets, the latest retailer to address customer backlash against disposable packaging and utensils.

headline.text: Sex Abuse to Cast Shadow Over Pope’s Ireland Visit

articles.summary: When Pope Francis lands in Ireland on Saturday, he will be visiting a once-devout Catholic society that is increasingly challenging the church’s authority—and where anger is running high over decades of sexual abuse of minors by Catholic priests.

headline.text: Australia’s Prime Minister Poised to Step Down

articles.summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull said he would step down if a majority of lawmakers in his party calls for a leadership vote as uncertainty has paralyzed the government for days and drawn criticism.

headline.text: Britain Ramps Up Preparations for No-Deal Brexit

articles.summary: The U.K. government published advice for British businesses on how to prepare for an abrupt break with the EU, a move aimed at underscoring to Brussels that it is serious about walking away from talks if it doesn’t get a satisfactory deal.

headline.text: At Hedge Funds, Where Are the Women?

articles.summary: Women run only two of the top 50 hedge funds. Instead, they tend to cluster in investor relations or marketing, positions rarely involved in important investment decisions.

articles.summary: Michael Cohen told a judge he made payments to two women “for the purpose of influencing the election” and acted at the direction of Donald Trump.

headline.text: Suspect in Murder of Iowa College Student Held on $5 Million Bond

articles.summary: An Iowa judge has ordered a man charged in the kidnapping and murder of a college student to be jailed on a $5 million, cash-only bond.

headline.text: ‘Sweeney Todd’ to Close, Even as Audiences Eat It Up

headline.text: Carlyle Group Fund Bets on Long Island City

articles.summary: A fund managed by the Carlyle Group agreed to pay $284 million for a luxury rental tower in Long Island City, Queens, marking a milestone for the neighborhood.

articles.summary: New York City’s freelancers will soon have a free place to hone their skills, talk shop and get help finding a gig.

articles.summary: The New York Public Library is posting classic novels and short stories to its Instagram account.

headline.text: Illegal Immigrant Charged With Murder of Missing Iowa Student

headline.text: Is Violence in Afghanistan a Prelude to Diplomatic Activity?

articles.summary: The Taliban and Islamic State fighters have killed more than 300 people in Afghanistan in the last week or so. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib asks if this might be a lead-in to diplomatic activity. Photo: AP

headline.text: Samsung Galaxy Note 9 Review: The All-The-Things Phone

articles.summary: Samsung's newest phone has more features, options and possibilities than the rest. WSJ's David Pierce reviews this big, fast, funky phone made for power users. Photo/Video: Emily Prapuolenis/The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: Mortar Fire Rocks Afghan Capital During Eid Address

articles.summary: The sound of mortar fire resonated near Kabul’s presidential palace as Afghan President Ashraf Ghani was giving a speech marking the beginning of a Muslim holiday. Photo: Reuters

headline.text: North and South Korea Try Soft Diplomacy

articles.summary: Pyongyang and Seoul are pushing ahead with symbolic inter-Korean exchanges—family reunions, joint sports teams and cultural events—amid concerns that denuclearization efforts have hit an impasse. Photo: AP and Getty Images

headline.text: Worst Floods in a Century Lash Southern India

articles.summary: More than 350 people have died and hundreds of thousands have lost their homes, according to the Associated Press, as weeks of torrential rain have caused massive flooding in the popular tourist state of Kerala. Photo: AP

headline.text: Women Are Running for Office in Record Numbers

articles.summary: There has been an explosion of women candidates in 2018. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains how Democratic and Republican women are running for office and winning primaries. Photo: Getty

headline.text: How Cohen’s Guilty Plea Could Impact President Trump

articles.summary: President Trump’s former personal attorney Michael Cohen pleaded guilty to eight criminal charges on Tuesday. WSJ’s Shelby Holliday explains how Cohen’s plea agreement could impact the president. Photo: Associated Press

headline.text: How We Got to the Longest Bull Run in History

articles.summary: Wall Street is now in the longest bull market in history. How did it get there? WSJ's Ken Brown walks us through the record-breaking bull run.  Photo illustration: Heather Seidel/The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: Paul Manafort Convicted: How the Trial Unfolded

articles.summary: A jury found Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign manager, guilty of eight counts of fraud, but couldn't reach a verdict on 10 other counts. Photo: Associated Press

headline.text: Will the Cohen and Manafort Cases Impact the Midterms?

articles.summary: The cases of Michael Cohen and Paul Manafort could drive President Trump to the campaign trail before the midterms. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib explains. Photo: Getty

articles.summary: The Taliban and Islamic State fighters have killed more than 300 people in Afghanistan in the last week or so. The WSJ's Gerald F. Seib asks if this might be a lead-in to diplomatic activity. Photo: AP

headline.text: This 22-Acre Island is Montana's Largest Private Estate

articles.summary: Shelter Island is home to Montana's largest private estate, which was completed in 2011.

headline.text: Here's How China Can Escalate a Trade Dispute With the U.S.

articles.summary: China has pledged to retaliate against U.S. tariffs in “equal scale and equal strength.” In addition to tariffs, here are three ways Beijing could hit back at Washington. Photo composite: Adele Morgan/The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: Samsung Galaxy Note 9 Review: The All-The-Things Phone

articles.summary: Samsung's newest phone has more features, options and possibilities than the rest. WSJ's David Pierce reviews this big, fast, funky phone made for power users. Photo/Video: Emily Prapuolenis/The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: A Grade II-listed House in Surrey on Five Acres

articles.summary: Known as Barhatch Farm, the Grade II-listed house is a "seriously historic house," according to listing agent Lottie Geaves of Savills.

headline.text: Mortar Fire Rocks Afghan Capital During Eid Address

articles.summary: The sound of mortar fire resonated near Kabul’s presidential palace as Afghan President Ashraf Ghani was giving a speech marking the beginning of a Muslim holiday. Photo: Reuters

headline.text: Engine Names IPG Agency Executive Its New CEO

articles.summary: Ad holding company Engine has hired Kasha Cacy as global chief executive, tapping an ad industry veteran who will be charged with simplifying the company’s offering to clients

headline.text: The Woman Behind New York Times’ Risky but Rewarding Strategy

articles.summary: Meredith Kopit Levien, who became chief operating officer last year, has pursued nontraditional advertising deals as she tries to navigate unforgiving waters.

headline.text: Mark Penn’s Stagwell Group Raises $260 Million

articles.summary: Private-equity firm AlpInvest brings the total funding raised by the former Microsoft strategist and Clinton adviser’s marketing group to around $510 million

headline.text: Activist Elliott Management to Push Nielsen Holdings to Sell

articles.summary: Activist investor Elliott Management has taken a big stake in Nielsen Holdings and plans to push the TV-ratings company to sell itself.

headline.text: How Tennis Plans to Attract Younger Players

articles.summary: Amy Choyne, the USTA’s marketing chief, wants families to see the sport as less expensive, less competitive and not so difficult.

bullets.title: Heineken’s Strategy in a Stagnant Beer Market

headline.text: Snapchat’s Users Slide in Latest Setback for Social Media

articles.summary: Snap reported that its number of daily active users fell by 2%, marking its first decline since being founded in 2011.

headline.text: MDC Partners Grapples With Client Cutbacks in Second Quarter

articles.summary: MDC Partners missed its earnings expectations in the second quarter, as the advertising-holding company continued to struggle with client cutbacks, slowdown in new business processes and other business challenges.

headline.text: Ad Giant Omnicom Agrees to Buy Small Consulting Firm

articles.summary: Omnicom Group has agreed to acquire Dallas-based consulting firm Credera, the latest instance of an ad-services business investing in consulting services.

headline.text: Facebook’s New Message to WhatsApp: Make Money

articles.summary: WhatsApp detailed plans to sell ads and charge big companies that want to reach their customers through its service, launching its first major revenue streams as growth at Facebook’s main app is starting to decelerate.

bullets.title: New Facebook, Instagram Tools Aim to Curb Your Binge

headline.text: ComScore to Debut First Ad Product Under New CEO

articles.summary: ComScore is preparing to launch a new product that measures ad views across platforms like TV and mobile, the first big move by new Chief Executive Bryan Wiener, who has been charged with turning around the beleaguered business.

headline.text: Facebook’s Next Challenge: Less Data to Target Ads

articles.summary: Facebook’s advertisers in Europe are on the front lines of its efforts to tighten privacy practices, and their frustrations help explain why the social-media giant’s troubles are far from over.

bullets.title: Facebook’s Hard Fall Shows the Pitfalls of Big Data

headline.text: WPP Veteran Read Has Emerged as Leading CEO Choice

articles.summary: WPP PLC executive Mark Read has emerged as the leading contender to take over as chief executive of the advertising giant, according to people familiar with the matter, following the departure of founder Martin Sorrell.

headline.text: Facebook’s Challenge: Draw More Ad Dollars Beyond Core Platform

articles.summary: With Facebook’s relentless growth no longer a given on its main platform, the social-media titan now faces a question that was previously an afterthought: How to squeeze more money from its other apps and services?

headline.text: Amazon’s Profit Soars to Record

articles.summary: Amazon’s profit topped $2 billion for the first time, powered by the company’s newer services businesses that are ushering it into an era of swelling profitability.

bullets.title: Analysis: Amazon Makes Its Payday

headline.text: AMC Partners With Sorenson to Sell Targeted TV Ads

articles.summary: AMC will be able to serve different ads to different households using Sorenson technology, and charge a premium

headline.text: Viewers Cut the Cable TV Cord Faster Than Expected

articles.summary: Research firm estimates the ranks of U.S. cord-cutters will grow this year by 8 million, or nearly 33%, to 33 million.

headline.text: IPG Delivers a Dose of Good News for an Ad Industry Facing Challenges

articles.summary: Interpublic Group of Cos. beat expectations for the second quarter and raised its forecast for the year.

headline.text: WPP in Talks to Sell Minority Stake in Chinese Unit

articles.summary: WPP has held talks to sell a minority stake in its operations in China, as the world’s largest advertising company reviews its business after founder Martin Sorrell’s exit.

headline.text: Shares in Ad Giants Fall as Publicis Sales Disappoint

articles.summary: Shares in some of the biggest ad companies tumbled after Publicis reported revenue below expectations, heightening investors’ concerns.

headline.text: Big Advertisers Embrace Blockchain to Root Out Digital Spending Waste

articles.summary: Nestle, Anheuser-Busch and Bayer are among the big consumer marketers using blockchain to avoid the so-called advertising tech tax, or wasted spending on digital ads.

headline.text: The Morning Download: Democratic National Committee Reports Attempted Hack of Voter File

articles.summary: The DNC contacted the Federal Bureau of Investigation this week to report an unsuccessful phishing attack intended to access a voter database. A Democratic official told the Journal the move was “the beginning of a sophisticated attempt to hack into our voter file.”

headline.text: Federal Health Agency CIO Moves to Surgeon General’s Office

articles.summary: Beth Killoran leaves the top IT post at the Department of Health and Human Services to help develop IT strategy within the Office of the Surgeon General, the agency said.

headline.text: Wall Street Finds Limits with Current AI Applications

articles.summary: Experts who are experimenting with various aspects of artificial intelligence at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Morgan Stanley say artificial intelligence could be useful in detecting fraud and reducing errors in algorithmic trading, but there are still many limitations with the technology as it exists today.

media.credit: Sara Castellanos / The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: The Morning Download: Wall Street Finds AI Smart, but Not Human Smart

articles.summary: Snippets of code can do much of the job of a trader, but when it comes to answering questions that need contextual understanding and financial acumen, AI algorithms are easily fooled, says Ambika Sukla, executive director of machine learning and AI at Morgan Stanley.

headline.text: Farmers Insurance’s New CIO Sees AI Improving Claims Process

articles.summary: Farmers Insurance Group Inc. has hired Paul Wilson as its new chief information officer, and his priorities will include overseeing emerging technologies projects and accelerating product delivery, both of which could help drive competitive advantage for the company, he said.

headline.text: AIG Names John Repko Chief Information Officer

articles.summary: Mr. Repko comes from Johnson Controls where he was global CIO since 2016.

headline.text: The Morning Download: Verizon’s Oath Takes Hybrid Cloud Approach to Integration

articles.summary: The company's efforts to develop a shared infrastructure among 50 separate online brands are underpinned by a hybrid-cloud strategy, leveraging private-cloud capabilities in Oath’s own data centers, while expanding use of public-cloud services via Amazon Web Services.

headline.text: United Technologies Buys Analytics Firm Predikto to Boost Predictive Maintenance

articles.summary: Predikto’s tools will be integrated with UTC’s products and services, and will be available for use by UTC’s business units, which include jet-engine maker Pratt & Whitney, elevator manufacturer Otis and air conditioner and furnace maker Carrier.

headline.text: Oath Takes Hybrid-Cloud Approach to Integrate Data

articles.summary: The Verizon media subsidiary is leveraging its own data centers and public-cloud services to help unlock and share data spread across Yahoo, AOL and dozens of other online businesses, the company’s CTO says

headline.text: The Internet Identity Challenge: Nobody Knows You’re a Dog

articles.summary: In a world increasingly governed by digital transactions and data, the existing methods for verifying someone's identity  are far from adequate. CIO Journal Columnist Irving Wladawsky-Berger shares the findings of one report which points to a policy agenda for improving the privacy and security of digital systems and helping combat identity fraud.

headline.text: Shipbuilder Wants to Bring Mobile Tech, Digital Tools to Aircraft Carrier Construction

articles.summary: Amid mounting pressures from company executives and the U.S. government to build more ships for less money, the U.S. Navy’s supplier of aircraft carriers plans to speed up the design and manufacturing of ships by using augmented reality and mobile software.

headline.text: Intelligence Community CIO Seeks to Boost IT Integration

articles.summary: John Sherman says he wants to strike a balance between setting standards and avoiding a ‘wild west’ of intelligence agencies deploying their own applications.

headline.text: Large Companies Increasingly Comfortable with Startups as Business Partners

articles.summary: Large companies increasingly are willing to work with early-stage startups and set up corporate venture capital arms as they pursue digital transformation, venture capitalists said Tuesday at an event hosted by enterprise software vendor SAP SE’s startup accelerator program.

media.credit: Sara Castellanos The Wall Street Journal

headline.text: Avon Looks for Tech Makeover With New Hires, Digital Board Plans

articles.summary: Benedetto Conversano, most recently global CIO at Portuguese food distributor and specialty retailer Jeronimo Martins, is expected to help Avon develop a new digital strategy while standardizing technology delivery across the firm.

headline.text: Bank of China to Raise Fintech Spending, Pursue Blockchain Projects

articles.summary: The state-run lender’s CIO recently shared details on the bank’s blockchain efforts as he unveiled plans to significantly boost investing in fintech tools as U.S. banks take a slower approach.

headline.text: RPA Provides a Lightweight, Agile Approach to Automation

articles.summary: Robotic process automation aims to improve the operational efficiency of office and service workers by automating tedious, repetitive tasks such as those associated with widely used horizontal processes in HR, finance and accounting, and IT services.

headline.text: Election Tech Providers Join Cybersecurity Group to Bolster Systems Ahead of Midterms

articles.summary: A group of elections technology vendors on Wednesday announced plans to partner with an IT-focused cybersecurity information sharing group to better protect voting infrastructure amid allegations of a widespread Russian effort to interfere in the 2016 U.S. election.

headline.text: DreamWorks Looks to Reanimate Business With Advanced Analytics

articles.summary: “From a pure data and computational aspect … you get nothing for free,” CTO Jeff Wike tells CIO Journal. "Every blade of grass, every eyelash, every drop of rain has to be built from scratch, and time and time again.”

headline.text: General Dynamics Taps Insider to Lead Federal IT Push

articles.summary: Christopher Marzilli, a 20-year veteran at the defense giant, will oversee its growing federal information technology division

headline.text: MGM Resorts Bets on Tech Talent as AI Transforms Hospitality Industry

articles.summary: MGM Resorts International is hiring technologists who can help the global entertainment resort company develop consumer-facing software in areas such as artificial intelligence, as technology becomes ever more central to its future growth.

headline.text: Lowe’s Names New CFO

articles.summary: Lowe’s Cos. announced that David Denton, the current finance chief of CVS Health Corp., will assume the finance chief post at the home-improvement retailer.

headline.text: The Morning Ledger: U.S. Seizes on China’s Woes as Trade Talks Start

articles.summary: U.S., China launch two days of trade talks; Target's same-store sales soar; Australia follows U.S. in banning Huawei from its 5G network.

headline.text: A Tax Change Threatens to Hit Insurers When Most Vulnerable

articles.summary: Some large U.S. insurance companies are seeking clarity from regulators on a tax provision that threatens to pinch their bottom line.

headline.text: Hertz Nabs CFO From Nielsen

articles.summary: Car-rental giant Hertz Global Holdings named Jamere Jackson, the former finance chief of Nielsen Holdings, to lead its finance team.

headline.text: Hershey CFO to Retire in 2019

articles.summary: Hershey’s finance chief Patricia Little is leaving the candy maker at a time of rising costs and changing consumer tastes toward healthier snacks.

headline.text: Planet Fitness Expands Even as Mall Vacancies Rise

articles.summary: Planet Fitness is the rare mall tenant expanding its share of commercial real estate even as many retailers shrink their physical footprint as more commerce moves online.

headline.text: Equipment Maker Manz Expands Client List After Losing Apple Deals

articles.summary: German equipment manufacturer Manz AG is expanding its customer base to reduce the risks from relying on a few large clients, the company’s finance chief said.

headline.text: New Rules Look to Make Insurance Contracts More Transparent for Investors

articles.summary: Investors should see clearer and more up-to-date numbers about the financial health of U.S. life insurers under a long-planned set of changes to insurance accounting unveiled Wednesday, rule makers say.

headline.text: Netflix CFO to Step Down

articles.summary: Netflix said Chief Financial Officer David Wells plans to step down as soon as the company picks a successor.

headline.text: Germany’s Merck Boosts Hedges Against Currency Gyrations

articles.summary: German drugmaker Merck KGaA ramped up its currency hedging efforts in recent months as wild swings in exchange rates took a bite out of earnings.
